description.text: In this image from the Ajanta Art Calendar Mfg Co, Madras, Calcutta, a couple can be seen romantically embracing each other. The title indicates that the couple are Salim and Anarkali. The woman is wearing a shiny, transparent sari, has mehndi on her hands and is wearing golden jewellery. The man, Salim, is clad in green and is wearing a red turban which sports a white feather. A tree and a crescent moon can be seen in the background.

The title indicates that the couple are Salim and Anarkali. The woman is wearing a shiny, transparent sari, has mehndi on her hands and is wearing golden jewellery. The man, Salim, is clad in green and is wearing a red turban which sports a white feather. A tree and a crescent moon can be seen in the background. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Due to the lack of evidence and sources, the story of Salim and Anarkali is widely accepted to be either false or heavily embellished. It tells the story of a court dancer Anarkali and the prince Salim. Prince Nuruddin Salim, later Emperor Jehangir, son of the great Mughal emperor Akbar is the Salim referred to here. Salim's father, emperor Akbar, was angered by his son being in love with an ordinary courtesan. The story ends with Salim being sent by the king on a mission and with Anarkali being entombed alive in a brick wall. Mughal-E-Azam, the Hindi movie is based on this legendary love story of prince Salim and Anarkali. The difference is that in the movie Akbar spares Anarkali her life and lets her go away. The story of the movie was adapted from a famous stageplay titled “Anarkali”. In 1953, before Mughal-E-Azam, another film titled “Anarkali” was made. Bina Rai played the title role, while the famous actress Madhubala played the title role in the later film (sp)
